title: 107_hr4112
content: The Medicare Rural Access Preservation Act of 2002 includes provisions such as a 2-year hold-harmless for sole community hospitals, a 20 percent increase in Medicare payment for home health care in frontier areas, an adjustment in critical access hospital bed limit, a 15 percent increase in Medicare payment for hospice care in frontier areas, and treatment of eligibility for hospice care. Section 1833(t)(7)(D) of the Social Security Act is amended to provide temporary treatment for sole community hospitals regarding covered OPD services. Additionally, there is a 20 percent increase in Medicare payment for home health care in frontier areas. Section 1895(b)(4)(A) of the Social Security Act is amended to increase payment by 20% for home health services in frontier areas from January 1, 2003, to January 1, 2007. The term 'frontier area' refers to a county with a population density of less than 7 persons per square mile. The Social Security Act is amended to allow hospitals to exceed the 15-bed limit if they maintain an average of no more than 12 beds annually. The Social Security Act is amended to allow hospitals to exceed the 15-bed limit if they maintain an average daily inpatient census of acute care patients of not more than 12. The effective date for these amendments is January 1, 2003. SEC. 5. 15 PERCENT INCREASE IN MEDICARE PAYMENT FOR HOSPICE CARE IN FRONTIER AREAS. Payment rates for hospice care in frontier areas to be increased by 15 percent from 2003 to 2007. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows payment for hospice care even if the individual is not terminally ill but dies within 6 months of admission. The effective date for this amendment is January 1, 2003. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will evaluate the standards used by fiscal intermediaries in denying physician certifications under the Act. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will evaluate the impact of decisions on length of stay for terminally ill individuals under the Social Security Act. A report on this evaluation will be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of the Act.
